comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Sydney Harbour Bridge, and we'd love to have this added to the group! -- Seen in your Sydney Harbour Bridge set. (?)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Rather a sad story to this ship. See this blog - www.mulhollandnet.com/2008/02/08/helen-b-stirling-oregon-... , which includes two other photos of the "Helen B Stirling" squeezing under the unfinished Sydney Harbour Bridge. . The ship arrived in Sydney in March 1930 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16637511 She is declared unseaworthy - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16677245 Dances were held on board - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16700174 She is used for firewood - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16968970 She was destroyed by fire 24/3/1934 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17065501

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content: Interesting articles beachcomberaustralia some of which I had come across when researching this ship a few years ago as part of research into her sister ship and wondered about the 05/03/1931 date as she couldn't have sailed into Sydney after having been declared unseaworthy - should the date of the photo above be 05/03/1930?  I really like the dances held on board!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/imagegallery] I think the poor old ship was just being towed around Sydney Harbour from one mooring to another (perhaps between dances?!), rather than arriving in Sydney. She is sitting high in the water, implying no cargo of imported wood. The tugs are also visible on a couple of other photos in the Series 12685 (Sydney Harbour Bridge, 1923-1933), which also have the date 05/03/1931, so it is unlikely to be a typo, or mistaken date - the series seems to follow a chronological order Also if it were March 1930 the Bridge arch was not yet joined (August 1930) and decking as seen here, not yet built. investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There was concern at the time (March 1931) about the clearance under the Bridge, as shown in these newspaper articles - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/29899497 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/4376744 (includes a photo of the 'Helen B. Stirling') trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/38896769 Perhaps this photo and the others in the series are meant to be proof of the Bridge clearance. The 'Helen B. Stirling' was a kind of crash test dummy.

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content: Good point about the arch, decking and sitting high in the water. According to a photo and record at the John Oxley Library, State Library of Queensland hdl.handle.net/10462/deriv/14388 "The 'Helen B. Stirling', a windjammer, is pictured being towed under the Sydney Harbour Bridge at low tide to its moorings where it will be used for dances during the Bridge Week celebrations." I think it would be correct to assume she was used both to test the clearance (it also makes for a good photo opportunity) and towed around for dances. I know her from my research and newspaper articles as Helen B. Sterling not Stirling. In 1927 both schooners were sold to Capt. E. R. Sterling from Grant Smith & Company and renamed Dorothy H. Sterling (Dorothy H. allegedly after Capt. E. R. Sterling’s wife) and Helen B. Sterling.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/imagegallery] Aha! The different spelling produces a whole lot more Trove articles and pictures, including one which mentions she was on her way to Kerosene Bay on this occasion - SMH 6/3/1931 p.12 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16759510 .

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content:
Kerosene Bay - apparently called Oyster Bay, then Sugar Works Bay, then Kerosene Bay and later named Balls Head Bay after Lieutenant Henry Lidgbird Ball who was the officer in charge of HMS Supply.  According to Wikipedia ships were broken up and burnt to the waterline in the bay.
Fascinating discussion beachcomberaustralia, I've enjoyed talking to you and will continue my research over the next few months and will be in touch by private mail as your input is most appreciated.  The two ships originally had ten other sister ships which were all BU by 1923-1932...........

comment._content: Thanks beachcomberaustralia. Do you have references that Helen B. Sterling was named after E.R.'s wife? My research says E.R. named Helen B's sister ship Dorothy H. Sterling after his wife Dorothy. Some references are trove.nla.gov.au/work/37454816?versionId=48847955 and www.moanaslsc.com.au/history.html Maybe he named Helen B. after his daughter? I need to get back to finishing my article on these two ships, I would also like to do a short documentary of them one day so this photo of the shipowner could come in handy.

comment.author: 32162360@N00

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content: None of the references about naming the ship Dorothy H. after his wife are original sources, so I don't know either.  Everything to do with these two ships is difficult because there were so many changes, e.g. they changed hands four times in 1928 alone!  I'll do some family history research for the Sterlings when I'm next at a library.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/imagegallery] Hi beachcomber and Mangrove Rat, we found that though many sources online state that Helen B Sterling was E R Sterling's daughter, US census records via ancestry.com state that she was in fact his wife! His children's names were: Ray Milton Sterling, Ethel May Sterling (which was also the name of Ray's wife!) and Dorothy H Sterling. To be honest, after viewing passport photographs of Ethel May Sterling, the lovely portraits from our collection (posted above), do not appear to be his daughters. Still conducting research into this fascinating family and will be updating with new photos and info over at our Flickr set: bit.ly/ScJLJ3 If you find out any more info on this family, please let us know! Thanks also to State Records NSW for posting this beautiful photograph. ANMM
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content: Thanks ANMM. I was going to check ancestry.com at the library tomorrow. I'll continue researching… it is strange indeed that both his daughter and daughter-in-law were called EM! In summary: In 1927 he named the two six-masted schooners Dorothy H. Sterling and Helen B. Sterling - DH after his daughter and HB after his wife (there had already been an earlier 4-masted schooner Helen B. Sterling lost at sea in 1922). In May 1926 he bought the Hawaii and named her Ethel M. Sterling after his daughter-in-law: “She was sold to Captain E.R. Sterling, of Seattle, in May 1926, who installed two 240 horsepower diesel engines. During this conversion, she retained her masts but lost her sails and bowsprit and became a ‘bald-headed four-masted schooner’. She was renamed the ‘Ethel M. Sterling’ after his daughter-in-law. The Ethel M. Sterling plied the trade routes until she was seized in San Francisco in September 1927, as her owners had never paid for the engines. The ship was subsequently sold to a woman in Los Angeles for use as a tender in the tuna trade. Proving too big for the job, she was sold again to the Santa Fe Mercantile Company and used for lumber movements. Sold once more to Mexican owners in 1933, she was fully converted to a powered motor boat and lost her masts.” Interesting reading her life story which ends as a rice ship (W. Lawson, Shipwrecks of the Cayman Islands, Aquapress, 2004). Pic of her here trove.nla.gov.au/work/167586386 There had already been an earlier 3-masted schooner Ethel M. Sterling, ex-J. M. Weatherwax), purchased by ER in 1916 and operated under the command of RM Sterling. Then of course there was also a Margaret F. Sterling! Ex-Vancouver, she was “the last of the famous fleet of Sterling multi-masted schooners which met with a remarkable series of misfortunes in the Australian trade”. A 4-masted schooner, MF was later renamed Trade Wind and converted to a floating base ship for the NZ service of Pan-American Airways. I kayaked past the wreck of the Dorothy H. Sterling yesterday :-)

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
It appears that Helen was his wife and Dorothy was his daughter.

It also refers to the crew of the ship being rescued when the ship was on the point of foundering in 1922.    I am not 100% clear whether this foundering ship in 1922 was eventually salvaged,  or the 1930-1932 ship was a different one.
